title:
Micro Plasma Actuator Location Effect on Complex Fluidic Behavior: An
  Optimization Study
abstract:
This study employs optimization techniques to enhance the positioning of a
dielectric-barrier-discharge plasma actuator on a curved surface, taking into
account diverse aerodynamic and physical scenarios. The optimization
methodology utilized here is Differential Evolution (DE), complemented by an
improved electrostatic model for solving electrostatic equations. In this
electrostatic model, two elliptic equations, governing electrical potential and
plasma density, are independently resolved, and their solutions are
subsequently incorporated as source terms within the Navier-Stokes equations.
Notably, contrary to prior research suggesting the placement of the plasma
actuator at the leading edge of the airfoil, our findings reveal that the
optimal position for plasma actuation falls within the range of 2 to 4 percent
of the chord length from the leading edge, contingent upon the prevailing
aerodynamic conditions. Furthermore, we elucidate a mathematical pattern in the
optimization data across a continuous domain, applicable to various geometries
and designs. This mathematical model articulates the optimal location as a
complex function, dependent on both the linear Reynolds effect and the angular
impact of the angle of attack.
